Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Add MSA/AAD Configuration steps to Readme" (#6093) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "NuGet.Server returns 406 instead of 409 on conflict" (#6094) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
When using `nuget push` to publish a package with ID and version already existing on my feed, I receive a 406 (Not Acceptable) error instead of a 409 (Conflict). Because a 406 is also generated if you submit a non-nupkg file, this makes error handling difficult in my CI/CD process as I cannot be sure if I submitted a bad file or if the package already exists. I am not sure if this is an issue with the server or the client, hence posting here.

```
PS C:\> nuget push C:\pathto\AwesomeLibrary.1.0.0.nupkg -verbosity detailed
NuGet Version: 4.6.2.5055
Pushing AwesomeLibrary.1.0.0.nupkg to 'https://nuget.mydomain.com/nuget'...
  PUT https://nuget.mydomain.com/nuget/
  NotAcceptable https://nuget.mydomain.com/nuget/ 347ms
nuget : Response status code does not indicate success: 406 (Not Acceptable).
At line:1 char:1
+ nuget push C:\pathto\AwesomeLibrary.1.0.0.nupkg -verbosity detailed
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : NotSpecified: (Response status...ot Acceptable).:String) [], RemoteException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : NativeCommandError

PS C:\> nuget push C:\pathto\AwesomeLibrary.csproj -verbosity detailed
NuGet Version: 4.6.2.5055
Pushing AwesomeLibrary.csproj to 'https://nuget.mydomain.com/nuget'...
  PUT https://nuget.mydomain.com/nuget/
  NotAcceptable https://nuget.mydomain.com/nuget/ 347ms
nuget : Response status code does not indicate success: 406 (Not Acceptable).
At line:1 char:1
+ nuget push C:\pathto\AwesomeLibrary.csproj -verbosity detailed
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : NotSpecified: (Response status...ot Acceptable).:String) [], RemoteException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : NativeCommandError
```

Doing some searching online, it looks like other people get 406 for conflicts, too, but [the API documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/api/package-publish-resource#response) specifies a 409 for conflicts. I can live with the difficulty but would prefer the documented behavior.

`nuget push` functions as expected if the package doesn't already exist.

## Details about Problem

Using NuGet.exe version: 4.6.2.5055
OS version: Win10 v1703 (15063.1112)

Using NuGet.Server version 3.1.2 running on Azure

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Stand up a NuGet.Server instance on Azure configured with an API key and to not allow package overrides.

2. Publish a package to that server using `nuget push`

3. Attempt to execute the same command again immediately.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Gallery:  cannot upload package via drag-and-drop in Edge" (#6090) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
[async-file-upload.js uses `FormData.set(…)`](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/blob/166d4c21134c11f0800aa7e0f0026a53cc583d48/src/NuGetGallery/Scripts/gallery/async-file-upload.js#L55), which is [not yet supported in Edge](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/catalog/?page=1&q=formdata).

Analytics query:
```
exceptions
| where timestamp > ago(30d)
| where type == "Object doesn't support property or method 'set'"
    and assembly == "https://www.nuget.org/Scripts/gallery/async-file-upload.js"
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "ApiController actions should not throw exceptions when called with an unparseable version" (#6089) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: If `VerifyPackageKeyAsync`, `DeletePackage`, or `PublishPackage` were called without a valid version string, they could throw because the `NuGetVersion.Parse` used in `GetHttpResultFromFailedApiScopeEvaluation` would throw. This fixes that issue.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet.Versioning.SemanticVersion" (#7055) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Hello,

I don't know if y'all have a Gitter? That would be better, probably for my question. However...

I'm looking at leveraging ``SemanticVersion`` for purposes of supporting the ``System.Reflection.AssemblyInformationalVersionAttribute`` and just wanted to posture a couple of questions along these lines.

1) Am I even in the correct forum for purposes of possibly leveraging [``SemanticVersion``](/NuGetArchive/NuGet.Versioning/blob/master/src/NuGet.Versioning/SemanticVersion.cs)? I would say possibly excepting for the fact that I found ``SemanticVersion`` code in a *NuGetArchive*.

1) What does the ``ToString`` incorporate? Does it support major, minor, patch, and ``label``? i.e. ``1.2.3-dev456``?

1) What sort of text can ``Metadata`` contain? Seems fairly open ended from what I could analyze from the ``SemanticVersion`` code, but I wanted to double check? i.e. ``1.2.3-dev456+someMetaData``

Thanks!

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Source-Only NuGet packages add <Compile Include="..." /> to csproj, resulting in build errors." (#7053) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @btodts on June 22, 2018 11:41_

### Steps to reproduce
Install a source-only NuGet package, e.g. https://www.nuget.org/packages/TinyIoC/. Upon installation, this adds a file to your directory (in this case: `TinyIoC.cs`).

### Expected behavior
As per https://aka.ms/sdkimplicititems, I'd expect the SDK to pick this file up for compilation using the globs in the SDK properties, without modifying the csproj file.

### Actual behavior
A Compile element is added to the csproj file: <Compile Include="TinyIoC.cs" />, leading to a build error:
> Duplicate Compile items were included. The .NET SDK includes Compile items from your project directory by default. You can either remove these items from your project file, or set the 'EnableDefaultCompileItems' property to 'false' if you want to explicitly include them in your project file.

Manually removing the Compile element from the csproj everytime NuGet packages are installed, is less than desirable. Using `<EnableDefaultCompileItems>false</EnableDefaultCompileItems>` and `<Compile Include="**/*.cs" />` (again, as per https://aka.ms/sdkimplicititems), results in other build errors (e.g. `error MSB3105: The item "Foo.cs" was specified more than once in the "Sources" parameter).



_Copied from original issue: dotnet/sdk#2356_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Custom TargetFramework names cause nuget restore to throw NRE" (#7052) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe):

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 4.6.1.5019

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): 2.1.300

VS version (if appropriate): 15.8.0 Preview 3 (27820.1.d15.8)

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: Not sure. I've read that this technique should work, so I assume it used to work. But this is the first time I've tried it.

I have a library that targets net45 and I want to add a net40 target to it. I'll need to test it, but my test project requires net45 or later, so I can't simply make the test project target net40. How can I have *two* net45 targets that test different versions of the product assembly?
I've read that one can make up any TargetFramework string they want, so long as they set the canonical properties for it to explain what it means. I've [tried that](https://github.com/Microsoft/vs-validation/commit/e85d79e26c276ff219edbba843b80b2625761a80) and NuGet restore throws a `NullReferenceException`, blocking my progress.

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

```ps1
git clone https://github.com/microsoft/vs-validation.git
cd vs-validation
git co e85d79e26c276ff219edbba843b80b2625761a80
cd src\Microsoft.VisualStudio.Validation.Tests
msbuild /restore
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "dotnet pack includes analyzers in nuspec dependencies" (#7051) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used : dotnet.exe

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): 2.1.300

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): win10 v1803 (17134.112)

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: don't think so, at least not in any dotnet 2.0 builds (didn't try earlier)

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. `dotnet new classlib`

2. `dotnet add package Stylecop.Analyzers`

3. `dotnet pack`

The resulting `.nupkg` / `.nuspec` has a dependency on the analyzers package which is only a development time dependency. Same happens for other packages, e.g. `xunit.analyzers`, so it seems to be an issue with how the `.nuspec` is generated.

## Other suggested things

### Verbose Logs

Please include verbose logs (NuGet.exe <COMMAND> -verbosity detailed | dotnet.exe <COMMAND> --verbosity diag | etc...)
[dotnet.pack.log](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/2128108/dotnet.pack.log)

### Sample Project

Please see the above repro steps - no other code is needed.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Update-Package -reinstall does not reinstall in packages folder" (#4292) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I want to develop changes to PackageA and test them from a consuming project "ConsumerApp" as I go, without constantly changing the package version. For local iteration and testing on the package before the real release. 

I'm using these steps:

1. Build a change to PackageA, without incrementing the version.
2. Re-publish PackageA to a local feed, on my development machine. This works fine (I delete the previous instance first). 
3. Force that new package into ConsumerApp to test the change. From Package Manager Console:  `Update-Package -Reinstall PackageA -ProjectName ConsumerApp`
(See log output below)

But the result is the older version of the package is still in the packages folder (under the Visual Studio solution). I can tell from the contents.
I expected it to get the re-built and re-published package. 

Possibly related: I can't manually delete the folder `C:\dev\ConsumerApp\code\packages\PackageA.1.0.0`, while Visual Studio is open. I think VS has it locked somehow. As soon as I close VS I can delete the folder. 
Could the Update-Package command be hitting the same restriction? I assume it should be removing that folder as part of the reinstall. If the command is trying and failing to do this, it's silent about it.

Other notes:
- This package only exists at the local feed. Not in any other package source.
- This package is published with symbols (so includes a src folder under the packages\PackageA folder)
- The local feed is at the top of my package sources in Visual Studio.
- The log below indicates it is retrieving again from the Local feed, but later also says `Package 'PackageA.1.0.0' already exists in folder 'C:\dev\ConsumerApp\code\packages'`.
- In practice you might increase the version the first time you start iterating, to avoid a clash with the version previously released. But you'll hit the same problem on the iteration after that.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "No dotnet restore --configuration option" (#7050) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @bcuff on June 21, 2018 22:52_

## Steps to reproduce
Create a csproj file with conditional package references

Example:
```xml
<ItemGroup Condition="'$(Configuration)' == 'NUnitLite'">
    <PackageReference Include="NUnitLite" Version="3.9.0" />
</ItemGroup>
```

## Expected  behavior
dotnet restore should respect the --configuration parameter.
```bash
dotnet restore --configuration NUnitLite
```

## Actual behavior
dotnet restore doesn't have a --configuration option

## Environment data
`dotnet --info` output:
```
.NET Command Line Tools (2.1.201)

Product Information:

```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "DevelopmentDependency package nuspec should not include dependency groups" (#7049) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I have a .csproj that builds to a package with a couple properties set:

```xml
    <developmentDependency>true</developmentDependency>
    <IncludeBuildOutput>false</IncludeBuildOutput>
```

This is a build authoring package, which should apply to all projects without regard to the project's target framework. Yet the generated nuspec file retains this xml:

```xml
    <dependencies>
      <group targetFramework=".NETCoreApp1.0" />
      <group targetFramework=".NETFramework4.5" />
    </dependencies>
```

This effectively blocks the package from installing to certain projects based on target framework. 

I believe there is no way to suppress generation of these dependencies without completely taking over the nuspec file, which is a huge burden since otherwise I've already written all the msbuild authoring to help nuget to generate the nuspec file.

Please offer a way to control/suppress the target frameworks for a package.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet.org API rate limits for package updates" (#24) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
|Spec wiki|Discussion issue|
|----------|------------------|
|*None*|https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4679|

We have been working on improving the package submission workflow to reduce the overall time it takes to publish the package (right from package push/upload) till it's available for consumption and search. 

As mentioned on our [blog post](https://blog.nuget.org/20180201/NuGet-package-publishing-workflow-behind-the-scenes.html), the package availability gets degraded multi fold whenever there is a large number package uploads/updates by a single owner that clogs the package submission pipeline. Until we are able to scale to handle the large submission rate, in the short-term, we plan to reduce the rate limits for package pushes or deletes (unlist) per user.

The current [documented rate limits](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/api/rate-limits#package-push-and-unlist) will be updated to the following new limits once implemented. This change will go live, **soon** (within a week or two):

## Package Push and Unlist

| API | Limit Type | Limit Value | API usecase | 
|:---|:---|:---|:--- |
**PUT** `/api/v2/package` | API Key | ~~100 / minute~~ **250 / hour** | Upload a new NuGet package (version) via v2 push endpoint 
**DELETE** `/api/v2/package/{id}/{version}` | API Key | ~~100 / minute~~ **50 / hour** | Unlist a NuGet package (version) via v2 endpoint
